pros: It is a large and growing company
Good opportunities for experience and networking
cons: The pay is low for work expectations
Low pay, well under market. Poor morale. Long-term talent running for the door. Toxic and incompetent leadership.

pros:
• Casual social environment 
• Can do homework on the job
• Get to know people on campus

cons: Difficult to advance, kind of click-y with the long timers

review_title: Relatively good benefits, equity and inclusion
cons: Marginal growth opportunities and dwindling benefits

review_title: Changing leadership is undermining a supportive, caring culture.
pros: USNH offers excellent benefits -- including tuition waivers to any of the member institutions (UNH, PSU, KSC, GSC), and great health and dental plans.  The historic culture of the organization has been close-knit, with colleagues sometimes gathering for impromptu cookouts at lunchtime, and always supporting one another personally as well as professionally.  It's been a great place to work.
cons: A recent leadership change has led to an upper management decision to relocate the offices from Lee to Concord.  The decision was reached without any staff input, and will drastically up-end their lives; the lack of respect of the new management for those actually carrying out the mission of the organization has severely impacted morale and is eroding the culture as employees search out new jobs in the area to avoid the hour-long commute.

pros: Benefits - excellent package that almost makes you want to stay and be mistreated.
cons: Many managers and directors who have PhDs, but no understanding of how to manage and motivate people. Employees are encouraged to secretly report each other's errors to management, so there's no trust. Some managers try to get hourly workers to do free overtime. Intimidating environment where they document every perceived human error, but ignore successes and extra efforts, keeping employees on the defensive. If you don't have an advanced degree, you are not worth talking to, except to talk down to you or give you more work that will require you to do free overtime. If you can't fit it all in, you have to do it on your own time or they'll severely criticize your performance.
